Either Patient with symptoms of severe acute respiratory illness (fever, cough, general condition requiring hospital treatment) AND information about travel or stay in the area of ??intense transmission of SARS-CoV-2 virus for up to 14 days before the onset of symptom OR Patients with any acute respiratory disease with at least one of the following criteria up to 14 days before the onset of symptoms: -close contact with a confirmed or probable case of infection with the new corona virus, or work at or visit a healthcare facility that treats patients with confirmed or probable acute respiratory disease caused by the new SARS-CoV-2. https://web.archive.org/web/20200407225119/https://www.zdravlje.gov.rs/vest/346428/algoritamstandardna-operativna-procedura.php

Intercity, urban and suburban bus and rail services have resumed as of 17/5.http://web.archive.org/web/20200521212855/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No restrictions on movement or requirement to stay home, but recommend staying home and social distancing measures.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200521212855/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

State of emergency was lifted on 17/5, public transport resumed. "There are no restrictions on movement for residents of all ages, but everyone is strongly advised to respect the social distancing measures when outside, avoid large crowds, maintain the distance of at least 6.6 ft from others, respect the limitations on public gatherings and use disinfectants and personal protection like gloves and face masks."http://web.archive.org/web/20200521212855/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

"The Serbian government announced that entry to Serbia for foreign citizens will require a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before arrival AND a “stay authorization” or “authorization to transit” from the Serbian government. The government of Serbia reportedly plans to launch a web portal where foreign citizens can apply for this authorization, but that web portal is not yet operational. The PCR test must be given by the national reference laboratory of the country the foreigner is coming from. Tests will not be required for children up to 12 as long as the parent/guardian has the test results. These requirements may change at any time."http://web.archive.org/web/20200521212855/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

As of 18 May, Air Serbia re-established commercial international flights from Belgrade to London, Frankfurt, Vienna and Zurich but with reduced frequencies, while flights to Sarajevo, Podgorica, Tivat and Skopje are set for the beginning of June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200521213820/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Serbia.pdf
This will be increased to 1000 as of June 1.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200528213329/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Serbia has "taken measures and set aside 5.1 billion euros to help the economy and citizens".  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528215655/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/156219/ec-praises-serbia-for-reforms-economic-measures.php
PRC tests no longer required on arrival.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200528214914/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/466518/od-petka-pcr-test-nece-biti-obavezan-pri-ulasku-u-srbiju.php

From May 22 general etsting available in various location for everyone at request. Paid. https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.danas.rs/bbc-news-serbian/korona-virus-i-srbija-kad-gde-i-kako-mozete-da-se-testirate-na-licni-zahtev/

Serbia and Hungary open their border. No quarantine or PRC tests are required on arrival.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200528213642/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/156522/hungary-opens-border-to-serbian-citizens.php    PRC tests not required by anyone entering Serbia.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200528214914/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/466518/od-petka-pcr-test-nece-biti-obavezan-pri-ulasku-u-srbiju.php

The government's official web portal on coronavirus continues to publish updates, news and new reports. The Ministry of Health even issued an information hotline (064 8945 235) for people to dial to address any coronavirus related queries. The government has also been posting updates and advisory on their official twitter account.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200613060729/https://covid19.rs/homepage-english/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200613061600/https://twitter.com/serbiangov
Public gatherings are limited to maximum 1000 people as of June 1.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

"Subject to social distancing measures and certain restrictions proposed by the Serbian Government the following are reopened:   * Retail stores, shopping malls and small business like groceries, car mechanics, beauty salons, barbershops, and farmer’s markets;  * Gyms and fitness centers, parks and public areas intended for recreation and sports;  * Cafes and restaurants  * Intercity, urban and suburban bus and rail public transportation;  * Gambling facilities and casinos that operate in objects not larger then 400 sq. meters;  * Kindergartens and preschool facilities."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618005223/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

"There is officially no longer a limit on the number of people allowed to gather outside in Serbia, Darija Kisic Tepavcevic, the country’s top epidemiologist and member of its Covid-19 taskforce, announced this afternoon (5 June). Events of an unlimited number of people may be held outdoors, while gatherings of 500 people or less are permitted inside – provided, in both cases, that at least one-metre social distancing is maintained between all guests."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618004300/https://www.iq-mag.net/2020/06/serbia-lifts-restrictions-on-outdoor-events/

"There is officially no longer a limit on the number of people allowed to gather outside in Serbia, Darija Kisic Tepavcevic, the country’s top epidemiologist and member of its Covid-19 taskforce, announced this afternoon (5 June). Events of an unlimited number of people may be held outdoors, while gatherings of 500 people or less are permitted inside – provided, in both cases, that at least one-metre social distancing is maintained between all guests."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618004300/https://www.iq-mag.net/2020/06/serbia-lifts-restrictions-on-outdoor-events/

“Several towns are now considered COVID-19 hotspots in Serbia. Kragujevac is one of them. It is a city of around 200,000 people in the center of the country. Now the local authorities have been forced to announce a state of emergency after reporting hundreds of new cases in just a few days.  (…) But, it doesn't appear the threat is being taken too seriously on the city's streets. Playgrounds in the town's center are full of children and parents and very few are wearing face coverings.”    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200629205921/https://newseu.cgtn.com/news/2020-06-29/State-of-emergency-called-in-Serbia-s-towns-as-COVID-19-cases-surge-RHpQ51bxh6/index.html

Some of the worst-affected areas have reintroduced a state of emergency, with further measures expected to be implemented countrywide as of Monday, 29 June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200629205921/https://newseu.cgtn.com/news/2020-06-29/State-of-emergency-called-in-Serbia-s-towns-as-COVID-19-cases-surge-RHpQ51bxh6/index.html
"Senior care centers,  schools and universities remain closed until further notice."https://web.archive.org/web/20200709214438/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

"As of 5 June, there are no more restrictions on the number of public outdoor gatherings, however, a preventative measure of physical distance must be applied – a distance of at least one metre. As for the closed space, the maximum number will be 500 people, instead of 100 as was previously allowed."https://web.archive.org/web/20200626083704/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Serbia.pdf
"Intercity, urban and suburban bus and rail public transportation" have reopened. https://web.archive.org/web/20200709214438/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

"On 6 May, the state of emergency and curfew were lifted. There are no restrictions on movement for citizens of all ages, but everyone is strongly advised to respect the social distancing measures and to follow the sanitary protocols."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200626083704/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Serbia.pdf

"According to the current algorithm, an infectologist at the designated clinic for infectious diseases or a general hospital, together with the locally in-charge epidemiologist, decides if the person fulfills the criteria for a suspected case and, if so, testing is being done"

On July 1 in response to a new wave of infections, the government introduced new measures including limiting hours of operation for restaurants and bars; and closure of swimming pools, spa and wellness centres.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200903125436/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
From 1st July, sports and entertainment events banned. https://web.archive.org/web/20200903125436/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

From July 1: mandatory use of masks in public transportation and indoor spaces and stricter measures in municipalities where state-of-emergency is declared.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200903125436/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

PM explained that the introduction of more stringent measures was necessary, and expressed hope that in five to ten days they will contribute to reducing the number of infected people in Belgrade, where the situation is the most critical.    According to her, a ban on movement and curfew would undoubtedly be the most effective measure, because it was already seen in March and April that it contributed to reducing the number of infected people in a short time.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200718091317/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/158523/restrictive-measures-to-help-curb-coronavirus.php

Minister for European Integration Jadranka Joksimovic stated all the medical equipment that Serbia bought in March and April from the funds donated by the EU and the Kingdom of Norway through the UN Office for Project Services UNOPS, has arrived over the last few days.    Joksimovic said that at today's government session a decision was made on the delivery of the last consignment of medical equipment to the Institute for Public Health "Milan Jovanovic Batut".  Some of the supplies arrived in April and May, for some we waited a bit, but they arrived at the right time, although we all hoped that the pandemic would weaken in this period, she pointed out.LinK:https://web.archive.org/web/20200718090720/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/158541/all-medical-supplies-donated-by-eu-norway-delivered.php

PM urged the people to avoid to go at public gatherings.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200718092640/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/158575/gatherings-pose-great-risk-for-spread-of-coronavirus.php

In the territory of the entire Republic of Serbia, regardless of whether a situation of emergency has been declared in a certain municipality or city, gatherings of more than ten people in public places in closed and open space are prohibitedAll measures adopted at today's session of the crisis response team will be valid from 17 July.  Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20200718093134/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/158743/stricter-measures-in-fight-against-covid-19-from-17-july.php

The Government of the Republic of Serbia launched the second aid package on 30 July. 'This package includes the payment of 60 percent of the minimum wage twice , as well as the postponement of taxes and contributions on wages for one month, and it is worth 66 billion dinars [c.667 million US$].' The benefits will be paid in two times, one by 10 August and another in September.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200806165949/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/480712/usvojen-pravni-okvir-za-sprovodjenje-drugog-paketa-ekonomskih-mera.php

"Deputy Director of the Institute of Public Health of Serbia "Dr Milan Jovanovic Batut" Darija Kisic Tepavcevic said that the COVID-19 crisis response team proposed to the government to make a decision that all citizens coming to Serbia from the territory of Croatia, North Macedonia, Bulgaria and Romania should have a negative PCR test that is not older than 48 hours.    In a statement to the press after the session of the COVID-19 crisis response team, she explained that the decision is valid from tomorrow,15 August, and does not refer to our citizens who come from the territory of those countries."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200817062634/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/159955/mandatory-pcr-test-for-citizens-of-four-neighbouring-countries.php

On August 24, cinemas and theaters reopened, with safety measures in place including having a limit of 500 spectators.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200903125436/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

From Tuesday 1st September 2020, schools have reopened in a staggered system, with grades 1-4 teaching hours held in the morning, and grades 5-8 to be held in the afternoon. However, attending classes is not mandatory, with online teaching and teaching on state-run TV being offered. Parents must drop off and pick up their children from school, where masks are mandatory for pupils in public areas, though not in classrooms. Teachers have to wear masks all the time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200903123713/https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/rest-of-the-world-news/schools-across-balkans-reopen-after-virus-shutdown.html

[Epidemiologist Darija Kisic Tepavcevic] praised teachers and pupils who she says are clearly adhering to the prescribed measures, as the incidence of schoolboys is lower than in the general population.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921075818/http://rs.n1info.com/Vesti/a641255/Krizni-stab-o-stanju-u-skolama.html
"Establishments with outdoor seating will be allowed to operate from 6:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m.  Establishments without outdoor seating will be allowed to operate from 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m."
No change in policy.

"Indoor and outdoor gatherings, with the exception of cinemas and theatres, are limited to 10 people."  http://web.archive.org/web/20200921075212/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/serbia/coronavirus

Further restrictions were introduced on 4 Dec, with a number of workplace sectors required to close on weekends (5 pm on Friday to 5 am on Monday). This includes restaurants, shopping centres, casinos, hair salons and sports facilities. All of the above are allowed to continue open between 5 am and 5 pm on weekdays. An exception is made to food delivery services, which are allowed to function 24/7.     "Grocery stores, shops, retail facilities, as well as newsagents, kiosks and the like, where, as a rule, customers do not enter the facility in order to make the purchase, can work on weekdays and weekends until 9 pm.    Pharmacies and gas stations (fuel sales) can work non-stop, every day without restrictions.    Open-air green markets will also work on weekends from 6 am. to 3 pm."    "Medical centres and laboratories can operate throughout the day, including weekends."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207201946/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/164342/tighter-anti-coronavirus-measures-in-effect-as-of-tomorrow.php

A:     On 30 December 2020, Minister of Health Zlatibor Loncar stated in Novi Sad that the vaccination of health workers began today and that those working in infectious diseases clinics and emergency centres have already been vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102195559/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165717/vaccination-of-health-workers-begins.php

A, C:    State Secretary of the Ministry of Health Mirsad Djerlek announced: "We plan to vaccinate about 11,000 people by the end of the week, with half of the vaccines being allocated to health workers and half to gerontology centers and social welfare institutions".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111210924/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165825/vaccination-of-11000-people-planned-until-end-of-week.php

A, C:      The Prime Minister Ana Brnabic stated that that there will be enough vaccines available for all citizens who want to be vaccinated against coronavirus (agreements exist for 8 million doses for 4 million of inhabitants). The plan for mass immunisation will be adopted by the crisis response team during the week of 18-24 January 2021.  Brnabic expressed the expectation that the first vaccination point will be opened at the Belgrade Fair by the end of the week of 18-24 January, adding that from 11 January, citizens will be able to apply to the system through which they will be able to express their desire to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111212830/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166035/preconditions-for-beginning-of-mass-vaccination-provided.php    Two groups coded as insufficient evidence to warrant higher code

Classes in primary and secondary schools will be continued from 18 January according to the dynamics that took place in September. High school students will attend classes every other week (half a class in a shift), and elementary school students will go to school every other day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111194136/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166089/all-epidemiological-measures-remain-in-force.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111202631/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166116/government-adopts-recommendation-of-crisis-response-team-to-keep-current-measures.php

The Education Ministry said earlier that elementary and high schools would reopen using the same model for classes that was in place since September 1 which means that elementary school children in grades 1 to 4 will go to school every day in smaller groups while grades 5 to 8 will go to school every other day and online. High school students will either go to school one week and have online classes every other week or stay at home for online schooling to the end of the year. Classes will be 30 minutes long instead of the customary 45 and the school year will be five days longerr because of the coronavirus pandemic.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210118234843/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/serbian-schools-start-second-semester-teachers-unhappy/

On 19 January, mass vaccinations began at the Belgrade Fair, Brnabic reiterated that mass vaccination of Serbian citizens is starting today and to that purpose, the first big vaccination site is opened at the Belgrade Fair and at the Torlak Institute. She specified that the first ones to be vaccinated are members of the Ministry of the Interior, the Serbian Army and other security services.    The Secretary of State appealed to the citizens to apply for vaccination in as many numbers as possible, but also to adhere to the protection and distance measures. Current policies remain in place, no tightening of restrictions has been announced.    Enabling work from home for all employees, wherever possible.  Restaurants, cafes, bars, clubs, shopping malls, betting shops, stores and services such as hairdressers, beauty salons, fitness centers, spas, gyms, and swimming polls will close at 8:00 p.m. every day, including weekends.  Theaters and movie theaters will close at 5:00 p.m. every day, including weekends.  Green markets will operate regular hours on workdays, and from 6:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. on weekends.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222184643/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222184118/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/sekcija/en/151926/covid-19.php

Current policies remain in place, no tightening of restrictions has been announced.    Prohibition of public gatherings with presence of more than five people indoors and outdoors. On 26 February, weekend restrictions for 27-28 February were introduced:  Bars and restaurants in the entire country will work tomorrow and the day after tomorrow from 6 am to 2 pm, after which time only food delivery will be allowed.  Food stands at ski slopes will also be opened until 2 pm only, whereas the establishments delivering food and drinks can perform that activity 24 hours a day.  Hotels in the entire country can serve food and drinks in their restaurants and café bars until 2 pm to all citizens, whereas from 2 pm to 10 pm this service will be available exclusively to the guests staying in that hotel or in some other categorised accommodation.  In addition, shopping malls, shops that do not sell food, bookmakers, casinos, children’s playrooms, gyms, fitness centres, indoor spaces for football and other sports will be opened from 6 am to 2 pm for the weekend.  However, sports facilities where competitions have been booked in advance will be available solely for that purpose after 2 pm as well.  The facilities that will keep regular working hours and to which the above-mentioned restrictions do not apply are food stores, pharmacies, petrol stations, doctor’s offices, dental clinics, laboratories, theatres and veterinary clinics.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308031500/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168513/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-for-the-weekend.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Hotels in the entire country can serve food and drinks in their restaurants and café bars until 2 pm to all citizens, whereas from 2 pm to 10 pm this service will be available exclusively to the guests staying in that hotel or in some other categorised accommodation.  In addition, shopping malls, shops that do not sell food, bookmakers, casinos, children’s playrooms, gyms, fitness centres, indoor spaces for football and other sports will be opened from 6 am to 2 pm for the weekend.  However, sports facilities where competitions have been booked in advance will be available solely for that purpose after 2 pm as well.  The facilities that will keep regular working hours and to which the above-mentioned restrictions do not apply are food stores, pharmacies, petrol stations, doctor’s offices, dental clinics, laboratories, theatres and veterinary clinics.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308031500/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168513/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-for-the-weekend.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

On 05 March, country-wide weekend restrictions for 06-07 March were introduced:  A decision was made to transfer high schools to online classes from Monday, 08 March.  Close all restaurants and shops from Saturday midday till Monday morning at 6 am.  Theaters will be able to work, scheduled sporting events can be held, but without an audience.   In the city of Nis, the flea market and car market would be closed for the next two weekends.    On Monday, everything will work as before the measures adopted at today's session.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033058/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/168853/tightening-anti-epidemic-measures.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308034043/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=05&nav_id=110548  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308033436/https://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2021&mm=03&dd=04&nav_id=110540  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308025958/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced for the upcoming weekend (13-14 March 2021) - from Friday 12 March 9 pm to Monday 15 March 6 am, all cafes and restaurants will be closed, as well as all shops (except grocery stores), beauty parlours, hair salons, bookmakers, casinos, children's playrooms, gyms, sports facilities ...    From Monday 15 March 2021, the measures as before the weekend will apply again, including enabling work from home for all employees wherever possible and limitation of opening hours of services and shops.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210315162138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169201/new-epidemiological-measures-in-force-as-of-tonight-at-9-pm.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315131251/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced for the upcoming weekend (13-14 March 2021) - from Friday 12 March 9 pm to Monday 15 March 6 am, all cafes and restaurants will be closed, as well as all shops (except grocery stores), beauty parlours, hair salons, bookmakers, casinos, children's playrooms, gyms, sports facilities ...    From Monday 15 March 2021, the measures as before the weekend will apply again, including prohibition of public gatherings with presence of more than five people indoors and outdoors. Excluded from this measure are work organizations, schools, stores, shopping malls and similar facilities, which are subject to the prescribed limit on the number of persons within the square footage of the facility (minimum 4 m2 per person).    http://web.archive.org/web/20210315162138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169201/new-epidemiological-measures-in-force-as-of-tonight-at-9-pm.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315131251/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New epidemiological measures were introduced starting from 22 March 2021 and do not include information about schools. No change to school closure policy was found.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328200027/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169612/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-as-of-monday-at-6-am.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New measures were introduced starting from 22 March 2021:  - Cafes, restaurants, night clubs and bars, and shopping malls will remain closed.  - Cafes and restaurants are allowed to sell food and beverages at a counter, and they can also perform delivery 24 hours a day. Hotel restaurants and cafes can only serve hotel guests until 9pm.  - All food sales facilities and cultural institutions (cinemas, theatres, galleries and libraries) can work until 9 pm, and all other facilities up to 8 pm, under the following conditions -  provide at least nine square metres per person or visitor; exceptions are fitness clubs, spas, gyms and the like where sixteen square metres per person must be provided.    Previous measures that remain in place:  - Face coverings are mandatory indoors and on public transport, as well as outdoors if contact with other people cannot be avoided.  - Public transport is limited to half of its declared capacity.  - Public gatherings of more than five people are prohibited indoors and outdoors. Excluded from this measure are work organizations, schools, and similar facilities, which are subject to the prescribed limit on the number of persons within the square footage of the facility (minimum 4 m2 per person).  - Employees should work from home wherever possible.  - Visits to patients in hospitals are banned.  - Visits to elder-care homes are limited to 15 minutes.  - The recommended distance between people outdoors is 1.5 meters.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210328200027/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/169612/new-measures-against-coronavirus-in-force-as-of-monday-at-6-am.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210328194016/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New rules have been implemented:  - All businesses and services that are allowed to work, may operate from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.  - Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens and patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures.  - Shopping malls, cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed; take-away food and drinks are allowed (delivery services may be provided 24-hour a day).  - All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. All businesses and services that are allowed to work, may operate from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.  Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens and patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures, including a limit of five people per table with a mandatory two-meter distance between tables.  Live music performances in gardens and patios are not allowed.  Shopping malls, cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed. However, all cafes, bars and restaurants may continue to sell take-away food and drinks over the counter. Delivery services may be provided 24-hour a day.  All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses.  Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210412182328/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/170874/opening-of-shopping-malls-return-to-schools-possible.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419210617/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No change in policies.   Continuing from April 19th: Pupils of higher grades of elementary school and secondary school students return to classrooms. Restrictions still apply to universities – not more than 100 people are allowed in closed spaces (amphitheaters, lecture halls, etc. ).    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419210329/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/171183/children-to-return-to-classrooms-as-of-19-april.php

No change in policy.  All businesses and services that are allowed to work, may operate from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.  Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens or patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures, including a limit of five people per table with a mandatory two-meter distance between tables.  Live music performances in gardens and patios are not allowed.  Cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed, but may sell take-away food and drinks over the counter. Delivery services may be provided 24-hours a day.  All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses.  Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503180001/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No change in policy.  The recommended distance between people outdoors is 1.5 meters.  Public gatherings of more than five people are prohibited indoors and outdoors. Excluded from this measure are work organizations, schools, and similar facilities, which are subject to the prescribed limit on the number of persons within the square footage of the facility (minimum 4 m2 per person).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503184652/https://www.osac.gov/Content/Report/b12c51a2-24a2-4e39-ba05-1b484bff5155

As of May 7th, bars and restaurants will be allowed to work indoors until 10pm, at 50 percent capacity, respecting the distance of 1.5 to 2 meters and without music. Previous policy restricted businesses to operate outdoors only.     Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens and patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures, including a limit of five people per table with a mandatory two-meter distance between tables. Live music performances in gardens and patios are not allowed. Shopping malls, cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed.  However, all cafes, bars and restaurants may continue to sell take-away food and drinks over the counter.  Delivery services may be provided 24-hour a day. All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person.  Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses. Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510082941/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/172177/bars-restaurants-to-start-working-indoors-as-of-tomorrow.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510083045/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510184716/https://www.osac.gov/Content/Report/b12c51a2-24a2-4e39-ba05-1b484bff5155

New measures include: (i) wage subsidies, including payment of ½ of minimum wages for all entrepreneurs and employees in SMEs and large companies for three months (RSD 69.8 billion); (ii) additional payments for employees in travel, hospitality, and art (RSD 4.4 billion); (iii) universal cash transfer of EUR 60 to each citizen over 18 years old, paid in two installments of EUR 30 each—in May and November (RSD 43.2 billion);(iv) a one-off payment of EUR 50 to all pensioners (RSD 10 billion);(v)a one-off financial assistance of EUR 60 to all the unemployed, paid in June (RSD 4.3 billion); and (vi) support for the transport sector and for city hotels (RSD 3.9bn).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210524002614/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change in policy since May 7th:     Bars and restaurants will be allowed to work indoors until 10pm, at 50 percent capacity, respecting the distance of 1.5 to 2 meters and without music. Previous policy restricted businesses to operate outdoors only.     Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens and patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures, including a limit of five people per table with a mandatory two-meter distance between tables. Live music performances in gardens and patios are not allowed. Shopping malls, cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed.  However, all cafes, bars and restaurants may continue to sell take-away food and drinks over the counter.  Delivery services may be provided 24-hour a day. All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person.  Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses. Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510082941/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/172177/bars-restaurants-to-start-working-indoors-as-of-tomorrow.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510083045/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510184716/https://www.osac.gov/Content/Report/b12c51a2-24a2-4e39-ba05-1b484bff5155

As of April 5, 2021 the Government of Serbia is reporting that fully vaccinated individuals who received their vaccinations in Serbia do not need to present a negative COVID-19 test, nor quarantine, upon return to Serbia. For vaccinated individuals who received their vaccination outside of Serbia, a negative PCR test taken 48 hours prior to arrival to Serbia is required  http://web.archive.org/web/20210730113443/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

A supplementary budget with new support measures was adopted in April 2021. New measures include: (i) wage subsidies, including payment of ½ of minimum wages for all entrepreneurs and employees in SMEs and large companies for three months (RSD 69.8 billion); (ii) additional payments for employees in travel, hospitality, and art (RSD 4.4 billion); (iii) universal cash transfer of EUR 60 to each citizen over 18 years old, paid in two installments of EUR 30 each—in May and November (RSD 43.2 billion);(iv) a one-off payment of EUR 50 to all pensioners (RSD 10 billion);(v)a one-off financial assistance of EUR 60 to all the unemployed, paid in June (RSD 4.3 billion); and (vi) support for the transport sector and for city hotels (RSD 3.9bn).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210524002614/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Testing can be scheduled for citizens of the Republic of Serbia, foreign citizens residing in the Republic of Serbia, as well as for foreign citizens without residence (tourists).    Fee for RT-PCR testing for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 virus on personal request for citizens of the Republic of Serbia, for foreign citizens with permanent residence or regulated temporary residence in the Republic of Serbia, as well as for members of foreign diplomatic or consular missions and their families is RSD 9,000.00 starting from January 1, 2021, and for other foreign citizens the amount of the fee for RT-PCR testing on personal request is RSD 9,000.00 starting from April 19, 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210921103358/https://euprava.gov.rs/usluge/6096

No policy change    Which vaccines are available in Serbia? Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca, Sputnik V, and Sinopharm  Those in Serbia interested in receiving a COVID-19 vaccine can express their interest at the Government of Serbia website gov.rs and clicking the green button marked “Pokreni uslugu” or “??????? ??????.” The next page has a statement that the form is not a consent for the vaccination, but only expressing your interest. Please note that expressing your interest does not guarantee that you will ultimately be selected to receive a vaccine from the Serbian Government. Click the green button to submit a request.  On the next page you will fill in your personal information, then answer questions about whether you are interested in receiving any vaccine or only a vaccine from a certain manufacturer, whether you have any underlying health conditions, and whether you are able to leave your residence.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210921102759/https://euprava.gov.rs/usluge/6224  http://web.archive.org/web/20210921090537/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210921093921/https://covid19.rs/homepage-english/

No policy change  Cafes, bars, and restaurants may now operate outdoor facilities with no closing time.  Indoor facilities may operate until 1:00 a.m.  Music is now allowed.  All retail stores may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.  All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210921090537/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/    Restaurants, cafes and bars are allowed to serve customers in their outdoor spaces without restrictions to opening hours, and indoors at reduced capacity, until 1am.  Retail stores may operate without restrictions to opening hours. Cinema screening start times are extended to 11pm, and box offices may remain open until this time.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210921090707/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/serbia/coronavirus    http://web.archive.org/web/20210921093921/https://covid19.rs/homepage-english/
